cross-site request forgery.eli5: It’s like someone tricking your browser into sending a letter you didn’t write — using your signature to do it.
cross-site request forgery.boss: CSRF is a type of web attack where a user is tricked into performing actions they didn’t intend, like changing account settings or making purchases, by abusing their authenticated session.
cross-site request forgery.sysadmin: Cross-Site Request Forgery (CSRF) exploits a user's authenticated session in a web application by submitting unauthorized commands on their behalf, often via hidden forms or image tags.
cross-site request forgery.use_case: A user clicks a malicious link in an email that causes their online bank to unknowingly transfer funds.

remote code execution.eli5: It’s like someone being able to control your computer from far away without asking you first.
remote code execution.boss: Remote Code Execution (RCE) is a critical vulnerability that allows an attacker to run code on a server or device from a remote location.
remote code execution.sysadmin: RCE vulnerabilities enable threat actors to run arbitrary commands or code on a target system via network inputs, often leading to full system compromise.
remote code execution.use_case: An attacker exploits a vulnerability in a web app to install malware on the server remotely.

privilege escalation.eli5: It’s like finding a hidden key in a house that lets you unlock rooms you’re not supposed to enter.
privilege escalation.boss: Privilege escalation occurs when a user or attacker gains higher access rights than they should, potentially accessing sensitive systems or data.
privilege escalation.sysadmin: This refers to exploiting a flaw to elevate privileges from a lower level (like user) to a higher level (like root or admin), compromising system integrity.
privilege escalation.use_case: A hacker with user-level access uses a flaw to gain administrator privileges on a server.

lateral movement.eli5: It’s like sneaking through different doors in a building once you’re inside, looking for the safe.
lateral movement.boss: Lateral movement is how attackers move across systems within a network after gaining access, searching for sensitive data or higher privileges.
lateral movement.sysadmin: Refers to the techniques used by attackers to move laterally between endpoints in a network post-compromise, often using legitimate tools like RDP or SMB.
lateral movement.use_case: An attacker accesses a user’s PC and then uses it to pivot into the internal finance system.

denial of service.eli5: It’s like someone jamming the line by calling you nonstop so nobody else can reach you.
denial of service.boss: Denial of Service (DoS) attacks aim to overwhelm a system or network so it becomes unavailable to legitimate users.
denial of service.sysadmin: A DoS attack floods resources like web servers or DNS resolvers with excessive requests, degrading or halting service availability.
denial of service.use_case: A website gets flooded with junk traffic, causing it to crash and become inaccessible.

distributed denial of service.eli5: It’s like hundreds of people shouting into a phone at the same time — you can’t hear anything useful.
distributed denial of service.boss: DDoS attacks use many computers or bots to flood a system with traffic, effectively shutting it down for real users.
distributed denial of service.sysadmin: DDoS attacks involve multiple compromised systems (often botnets) launching coordinated traffic floods to overwhelm and disrupt services.
distributed denial of service.use_case: A botnet floods an online store during a product launch, causing the site to go offline.

dns spoofing.eli5: It’s like tricking your GPS to take you to the wrong place that looks like the real one.
dns spoofing.boss: DNS spoofing involves faking DNS records to redirect users to malicious websites without their knowledge.
dns spoofing.sysadmin: A method where attackers corrupt DNS responses, rerouting traffic to malicious IPs by impersonating legitimate domains.
dns spoofing.use_case: Users type a bank’s URL but get redirected to a fake login page due to a spoofed DNS entry.

arp spoofing.eli5: It’s like someone lying to your devices, saying ‘I’m the boss!’ so they route everything through them.
arp spoofing.boss: ARP spoofing tricks devices in a local network into sending data through the attacker’s system, enabling data theft or tampering.
arp spoofing.sysadmin: A technique where an attacker sends forged ARP responses to associate their MAC address with the IP of another host, often the default gateway.
arp spoofing.use_case: An attacker on a shared Wi-Fi network intercepts credentials by redirecting traffic through their laptop.

mac spoofing.eli5: It’s like pretending to wear someone else’s name tag so you can use their privileges.
mac spoofing.boss: MAC spoofing involves changing a device’s hardware address to impersonate another, often to bypass access restrictions.
mac spoofing.sysadmin: Changing the Media Access Control (MAC) address of a network interface to masquerade as another device, often for evading filters or gaining unauthorized access.
mac spoofing.use_case: A student bypasses a university network block by spoofing the MAC of an allowed device.

ip spoofing.eli5: It’s like sending a letter with someone else’s return address so no one knows it was you.
ip spoofing.boss: IP spoofing fakes a device’s IP address to hide identity, mimic trusted sources, or bypass restrictions.
ip spoofing.sysadmin: Altering packet headers to forge the source IP address, often used in DDoS, MITM, or session hijacking attacks.
ip spoofing.use_case: An attacker hides their location by spoofing a trusted server’s IP in a cyberattack.

dns hijacking.eli5: It’s like someone changing your GPS directions so you end up at a fake store that looks real.
dns hijacking.boss: DNS hijacking redirects users from legitimate websites to malicious ones by altering DNS records or settings.
dns hijacking.sysadmin: DNS hijacking manipulates DNS resolution through compromised servers, routers, or malware, redirecting traffic to rogue IP addresses for phishing or surveillance.
dns hijacking.use_case: An attacker hijacks DNS settings on a public router to send all users to a phishing version of a banking site.

clickjacking.eli5: It’s like putting a fake button on top of a real one so when you try to like a post, you actually send money.
clickjacking.boss: Clickjacking tricks users into clicking hidden elements on a website, causing unintended actions like form submissions or liking content.
clickjacking.sysadmin: A UI redress attack where attackers use transparent or hidden frames to hijack user clicks, often bypassing security controls or stealing credentials.
clickjacking.use_case: A user thinks they’re clicking a play button, but it secretly shares a scam post on their social media account.

watering hole attack.eli5: It’s like poisoning a favorite coffee shop so when your enemies visit, they get sick.
watering hole attack.boss: A watering hole attack infects a popular site visited by a target group, delivering malware to visitors from that group.
watering hole attack.sysadmin: In this attack, adversaries compromise trusted third-party websites to distribute malware or gather credentials from high-value targets.
watering hole attack.use_case: Hackers infect a popular software vendor’s documentation site to target employees of tech companies.

drive-by download.eli5: It’s like catching a virus just by walking past a sick person — you didn’t click anything, but still got infected.
drive-by download.boss: A drive-by download is when malicious software installs silently when someone visits a compromised or malicious website.
drive-by download.sysadmin: A method where malware is automatically downloaded and executed without user interaction via browser or plugin vulnerabilities.
drive-by download.use_case: Visiting a news site infected with malicious ads causes a background ransomware install without any clicks.

typosquatting.eli5: It’s like building a fake ‘Amazzon.com’ store hoping someone mistypes the real one.
typosquatting.boss: Typosquatting takes advantage of common misspellings of URLs to trick users into visiting fake or malicious sites.
typosquatting.sysadmin: A form of domain impersonation where attackers register typo-variant domains of trusted brands to phish credentials or spread malware.
typosquatting.use_case: A user accidentally visits ‘paypaI.com’ (with a capital i), which steals their login info.

next-generation firewall.eli5: It’s like a guard dog that not only checks IDs but also watches behavior and scans your backpack.
next-generation firewall.boss: A Next-Generation Firewall (NGFW) goes beyond basic traffic filtering to analyze applications, users, and threats in real-time.
next-generation firewall.sysadmin: NGFWs integrate stateful inspection, deep packet inspection, app awareness, IDS/IPS, and sometimes SSL decryption to block advanced threats.
next-generation firewall.use_case: A company replaces its legacy firewall with an NGFW to detect malware hiding in encrypted web traffic.

web application firewall.eli5: It’s like a bouncer who reads what people are saying before letting them into a party.
web application firewall.boss: A Web Application Firewall (WAF) filters incoming traffic to protect websites from attacks like SQL injection or cross-site scripting.
web application firewall.sysadmin: WAFs inspect HTTP/HTTPS traffic and apply rules to block malicious payloads targeting application layer vulnerabilities.
web application firewall.use_case: An online store deploys a WAF to block common injection attacks and protect user data.

intrusion detection system.eli5: It’s like a home security camera that records everything and sends alerts if something weird happens.
intrusion detection system.boss: An Intrusion Detection System (IDS) monitors network traffic for suspicious activity and notifies admins of possible threats.
intrusion detection system.sysadmin: IDS tools passively monitor traffic and generate alerts when matching known threat signatures or behavior anomalies — without blocking traffic.
intrusion detection system.use_case: An IDS detects a brute-force SSH attempt and emails an alert to the IT team.

intrusion prevention system.eli5: It’s like a security system that not only alerts you but also locks the doors before the bad guy gets in.
intrusion prevention system.boss: An Intrusion Prevention System (IPS) actively blocks malicious traffic in real-time by analyzing and intercepting suspicious data flows.
intrusion prevention system.sysadmin: IPS tools sit inline on the network and prevent detected threats by dropping malicious packets, blocking connections, or resetting sessions.
intrusion prevention system.use_case: An IPS stops a known ransomware payload from reaching an internal file server.

siem.eli5: It’s like a giant control room where all the security cameras send their footage, and alarms go off when something strange happens.
siem.boss: A SIEM (Security Information and Event Management) platform collects and analyzes logs from across the organization to detect threats and support compliance.
siem.sysadmin: SIEM systems centralize security data from devices and applications, apply correlation rules, and provide dashboards and alerts for incident detection and forensic analysis.
siem.use_case: A SOC uses a SIEM to monitor real-time login data and investigate unusual logins across multiple sites.

soar.eli5: It’s like a robot assistant for your security team — it sees alerts and takes action fast without waiting for instructions.
soar.boss: SOAR (Security Orchestration, Automation, and Response) platforms automate repetitive security tasks and streamline incident response workflows.
soar.sysadmin: SOAR connects tools like SIEM, firewalls, and EDR to automate threat triage, enrichment, and response actions using playbooks and APIs.
soar.use_case: SOAR isolates an infected device, disables its network access, and creates a ticket — all within seconds of detection.

edr.eli5: It’s like having a smart security camera on each device that alerts you when something shady happens.
edr.boss: EDR (Endpoint Detection and Response) tools detect, investigate, and contain threats on laptops, desktops, and servers.
edr.sysadmin: EDR collects telemetry from endpoints to detect abnormal behaviors, analyze threats, and support response actions like rollback or isolation.
edr.use_case: An EDR system detects ransomware encryption behavior and quarantines the affected process automatically.

xdr.eli5: It’s like security guards from every floor of a building reporting to one boss, who sees the whole picture and can respond quickly.
xdr.boss: XDR (Extended Detection and Response) aggregates security data from endpoints, networks, cloud, and identity to detect and respond to threats holistically.
xdr.sysadmin: XDR unifies telemetry from EDR, NDR, email, and cloud sources, correlating events across vectors to identify complex attacks and automate remediation.
xdr.use_case: XDR links a phishing email to a malicious process on an endpoint and automatically removes the threat across systems.

mdr.eli5: It’s like hiring a 24/7 security team to monitor your home and stop break-ins while you sleep.
mdr.boss: MDR (Managed Detection and Response) is an outsourced cybersecurity service that continuously monitors, detects, and responds to threats on your behalf.
mdr.sysadmin: MDR combines EDR tools with human security analysts to deliver threat detection, investigation, and response for clients without internal SOCs.
mdr.use_case: A startup uses an MDR provider to monitor its environment and get expert remediation help when alerts trigger.

ndr.eli5: It’s like putting microphones in all the hallways so you can hear unusual noises and know when something’s wrong.
ndr.boss: Network Detection and Response (NDR) monitors network traffic to detect threats that might evade endpoint defenses.
ndr.sysadmin: NDR tools passively analyze east-west and north-south network traffic using machine learning and threat intelligence to detect lateral movement or suspicious activity.
ndr.use_case: A company uses NDR to detect internal lateral movement after a phishing attack compromises one endpoint.

antivirus.eli5: It’s like a guard dog that barks when a virus tries to sneak into your computer.
antivirus.boss: Antivirus software detects and removes malicious software from devices to protect data and systems.
antivirus.sysadmin: Antivirus uses signature-based and heuristic analysis to scan files, memory, and processes for malware, blocking or removing threats as needed.
antivirus.use_case: An antivirus program blocks a trojan trying to install from an email attachment.

anti-malware.eli5: It’s like a bug zapper that kills not just flies, but all kinds of creepy crawlers.
anti-malware.boss: Anti-malware tools protect against a wider range of malicious threats than traditional antivirus, including ransomware and spyware.
anti-malware.sysadmin: Anti-malware solutions detect, quarantine, and remove malware using behavioral analysis, signatures, and cloud-based threat intelligence.
anti-malware.use_case: An anti-malware suite detects a fileless malware script running in memory and stops it.

endpoint protection.eli5: It’s like giving every laptop and phone a personal security guard.
endpoint protection.boss: Endpoint Protection Platforms (EPPs) defend individual devices against malware, phishing, and unauthorized access.
endpoint protection.sysadmin: Endpoint protection tools combine antivirus, anti-malware, firewall, and application control to secure devices like desktops, laptops, and servers.
endpoint protection.use_case: A hospital installs endpoint protection on all staff computers to meet HIPAA requirements.

application whitelisting.eli5: It’s like only letting people into your party if they’re on the guest list.
application whitelisting.boss: Application whitelisting ensures only approved programs can run on a system, blocking anything unfamiliar or unauthorized.
application whitelisting.sysadmin: A security approach that permits execution of only pre-approved applications, often enforced through hash, path, or publisher-based rules.
application whitelisting.use_case: An IT team uses whitelisting to prevent unapproved software from running on point-of-sale terminals.

sandboxing.eli5: It’s like letting a kid play in a sandbox where they can’t break anything outside of it.
sandboxing.boss: Sandboxing isolates software in a controlled environment so it can’t affect the rest of the system if it misbehaves.
sandboxing.sysadmin: A technique that runs untrusted code in a restricted container to observe behavior safely and prevent damage to the host OS.
sandboxing.use_case: A malware researcher runs suspicious attachments in a sandbox to see what they do before releasing them.

data loss prevention.eli5: It’s like putting sticky notes on things that say ‘Do Not Remove’ so no one takes them.
data loss prevention.boss: DLP tools monitor and restrict sensitive data to prevent leaks, whether accidental or intentional.
data loss prevention.sysadmin: DLP solutions use rules to detect and block the transfer of sensitive information via email, USB, or uploads, helping enforce compliance.
data loss prevention.use_case: A DLP rule blocks an employee from emailing a spreadsheet containing unencrypted customer credit card data.

microsegmentation.eli5: It’s like adding locked doors between every room so a burglar can’t run around freely.
microsegmentation.boss: Microsegmentation limits lateral movement by isolating workloads and enforcing strict access between services.
microsegmentation.sysadmin: A network security technique that uses virtual firewalls to isolate individual workloads or applications, enforcing least privilege.
microsegmentation.use_case: A cloud provider uses microsegmentation to ensure a breached dev server can’t access the production database.

access control.eli5: It’s like using a keycard to get into the building — only certain people are allowed.
access control.boss: Access control ensures only authorized users can view or use specific systems and data.
access control.sysadmin: Access control systems define and enforce permissions using models like RBAC, ABAC, or discretionary rules to limit system interaction.
access control.use_case: A company uses access control lists to restrict who can access financial records.

rbac.eli5: It’s like giving people different colored wristbands at a concert — each one lets them into different areas.
rbac.boss: Role-Based Access Control assigns permissions to users based on their job roles to simplify security management.
rbac.sysadmin: RBAC structures user permissions around roles (e.g., admin, HR, support), assigning access rights based on role membership.
rbac.use_case: An employee in HR gets access to payroll systems while developers cannot view HR records — thanks to RBAC.

abac.eli5: It’s like letting someone in only if they meet specific conditions — not just based on who they are.
abac.boss: Attribute-Based Access Control uses user and resource attributes — like department or clearance — to grant or deny access.
abac.sysadmin: ABAC defines access policies using attributes (user, resource, action, environment) evaluated through Boolean logic to enforce rules dynamically.
abac.use_case: An ABAC policy allows only engineers in the US region to deploy production code after hours.

iam.eli5: It’s like the receptionist who checks everyone’s ID and decides where they’re allowed to go.
iam.boss: Identity and Access Management (IAM) handles user identities and what they can access, helping enforce security policies.
iam.sysadmin: IAM solutions manage user lifecycle, authentication, authorization, and auditing, often integrating with SSO, MFA, and directory services.
iam.use_case: A cloud platform uses IAM to control who can access virtual machines and storage.

mfa.eli5: It’s like needing both a key and a fingerprint to open a door.
mfa.boss: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) adds an extra layer of login security by requiring more than just a password.
mfa.sysadmin: MFA enforces two or more independent authentication factors: something you know, have, or are — like a password plus TOTP or biometrics.
mfa.use_case: An employee must enter a code from their phone in addition to their password when logging in remotely.

2fa.eli5: It’s like needing a bank card *and* your PIN — two steps to prove who you are.
2fa.boss: Two-Factor Authentication (2FA) is a simpler form of MFA that combines two verification methods to protect user accounts.
2fa.sysadmin: 2FA requires users to authenticate using two different factors — usually a password and a one-time code sent via app or SMS.
2fa.use_case: 2FA protects access to a payroll system by requiring both a password and a TOTP code.

audit logging.eli5: It’s like a notebook where everything someone does in your house gets written down.
audit logging.boss: Audit logging records who did what, when, and where within a system, which helps with security, compliance, and troubleshooting.
audit logging.sysadmin: Audit logs capture system-level events like logins, file access, and administrative actions for tracking changes and detecting anomalies.
audit logging.use_case: An admin checks audit logs to find out who deleted a database entry last week.

security logging.eli5: It’s like setting up cameras and writing down what each one saw all day.
security logging.boss: Security logging captures events and activities related to cybersecurity, helping detect threats and investigate incidents.
security logging.sysadmin: Logs generated by security systems — firewalls, antivirus, intrusion detection, etc. — used for monitoring and analysis by SIEM tools.
security logging.use_case: Security logs help identify an unauthorized login attempt from a foreign IP.

public key infrastructure.eli5: It’s like a digital notary that helps people know who to trust online.
public key infrastructure.boss: PKI is a system that manages digital certificates to enable secure, encrypted communication and identity verification.
public key infrastructure.sysadmin: A framework that uses asymmetric encryption, certificate authorities, and key pairs to authenticate users, devices, and services.
public key infrastructure.use_case: A company uses PKI to issue certificates for its internal apps to ensure secure communication.

certificate authority.eli5: It’s like the trusted person who hands out IDs at the front desk — if they vouch for you, others trust you.
certificate authority.boss: A Certificate Authority (CA) issues and verifies digital certificates used to secure websites and software.
certificate authority.sysadmin: A trusted entity that signs and manages SSL/TLS certificates, ensuring the identity of a website or device.
certificate authority.use_case: A website gets its TLS certificate signed by a trusted CA to avoid browser security warnings.

digital certificate.eli5: It’s like a digital version of a driver’s license proving your identity online.
digital certificate.boss: A digital certificate proves the identity of a server, user, or device and enables encrypted communication.
digital certificate.sysadmin: An X.509 file issued by a CA that binds a public key to an entity, enabling SSL/TLS and other secure protocols.
digital certificate.use_case: A server uses a digital certificate to enable HTTPS and prove it's authentic.

digital signature.eli5: It’s like a special stamp that proves you really wrote something — and it hasn’t been changed.
digital signature.boss: Digital signatures verify the authenticity and integrity of data or messages using encryption.
digital signature.sysadmin: A cryptographic hash of data signed with a private key to prove origin and detect tampering upon verification with the public key.
digital signature.use_case: A software update includes a digital signature so systems can verify it came from the vendor.

encryption.eli5: It’s like locking your message in a box that only someone with the right key can open.
encryption.boss: Encryption scrambles data so only authorized parties can read it, protecting privacy and security.
encryption.sysadmin: The process of converting plaintext into ciphertext using algorithms like AES or RSA to protect data at rest or in transit.
encryption.use_case: A messaging app encrypts texts so only the sender and receiver can read them.

decryption.eli5: It’s like unlocking that locked message box so you can read what’s inside.
decryption.boss: Decryption is the process of converting scrambled, encrypted data back into a readable format.
decryption.sysadmin: A cryptographic operation that transforms ciphertext back into plaintext using a matching key.
decryption.use_case: An employee decrypts a secure email using their private key.

authentication.eli5: It’s like showing your ID to prove who you are before entering a building.
authentication.boss: Authentication verifies that someone is who they claim to be — typically through passwords, biometrics, or multi-factor methods.
authentication.sysadmin: Authentication is the process of verifying identity using credentials like username/password pairs, certificates, tokens, or biometric factors.
authentication.use_case: A user logs into their email by entering their password and scanning their fingerprint.

authorization.eli5: It’s like getting access to only the rooms you’re allowed to enter once you’ve proven who you are.
authorization.boss: Authorization determines what a user is allowed to do or access after they’ve been authenticated.
authorization.sysadmin: The process of granting or denying specific permissions to authenticated users based on roles, policies, or attributes.
authorization.use_case: An employee logs in successfully but can only view — not edit — customer records due to their role.

symmetric encryption.eli5: It’s like using the same key to lock and unlock a treasure chest — both people need a copy.
symmetric encryption.boss: Symmetric encryption uses the same key for both encrypting and decrypting data, making it fast but requiring secure key sharing.
symmetric encryption.sysadmin: In symmetric encryption, the same secret key is used by both the sender and receiver. It's efficient for large data but requires out-of-band secure key exchange.
symmetric encryption.use_case: A file backup system encrypts and decrypts data using the same key to ensure quick performance.

asymmetric encryption.eli5: It’s like sending someone a locked box that only they can open, even though everyone has the lock.
asymmetric encryption.boss: Asymmetric encryption uses two keys — one public and one private — making it ideal for secure communication over the internet.
asymmetric encryption.sysadmin: This encryption method relies on a key pair: the public key encrypts, and only the private key can decrypt. It's used in SSL/TLS, SSH, and digital signatures.
asymmetric encryption.use_case: An email service uses asymmetric encryption so anyone can send a secure message using your public key, but only you can read it with your private key.

rsa.eli5: It’s like giving everyone a mailbox that only you can open with your special key.
rsa.boss: RSA is a widely used asymmetric encryption algorithm that allows secure data exchange and digital signatures.
rsa.sysadmin: RSA (Rivest–Shamir–Adleman) is a public-key cryptosystem based on the difficulty of factoring large primes. It's used in HTTPS, PGP, and digital certificates.
rsa.use_case: A web server uses RSA during the TLS handshake to securely exchange encryption keys with a browser.

aes.eli5: It’s like a super-secure vault that locks and unlocks using the same combination — fast and hard to break.
aes.boss: AES (Advanced Encryption Standard) is a government-approved algorithm for encrypting data with a symmetric key.
aes.sysadmin: AES is a symmetric block cipher standard used globally for securing data at rest and in transit. It supports key sizes of 128, 192, and 256 bits.
aes.use_case: A cloud storage service uses AES-256 to encrypt user data on disk.

ecc.eli5: It’s like solving a puzzle on a twisty path instead of a straight line — it gets the same result with less work.
ecc.boss: ECC (Elliptic Curve Cryptography) offers strong encryption using shorter keys, making it fast and efficient for devices.
ecc.sysadmin: ECC is an asymmetric algorithm that uses elliptic curves over finite fields for public key cryptography. It's preferred in constrained environments due to smaller key sizes.
ecc.use_case: Smartphones use ECC for securing app data without draining battery or performance.

sha.eli5: It’s like making a unique fingerprint for a file so you can tell if it’s changed.
sha.boss: SHA (Secure Hash Algorithm) is used to create a digital fingerprint of data for verification, often in encryption and blockchain.
sha.sysadmin: SHA is a family of cryptographic hash functions (SHA-1, SHA-2, SHA-3) that produce fixed-size digests for verifying data integrity.
sha.use_case: A software installer uses a SHA-256 hash to verify that the downloaded file hasn’t been tampered with.

md5.eli5: It’s like a quick signature for a file — but not very trustworthy anymore.
md5.boss: MD5 is an older hash algorithm once used for verifying data, now mostly replaced due to security flaws.
md5.sysadmin: MD5 (Message Digest 5) creates 128-bit hashes, but is considered cryptographically broken and vulnerable to collision attacks.
md5.use_case: MD5 is still used to quickly check file integrity in low-risk scenarios like personal backups.

hashing.eli5: It’s like turning a piece of data into a unique barcode you can’t reverse — just verify.
hashing.boss: Hashing creates a unique, fixed-size value from data that can be used for integrity checks and password storage.
hashing.sysadmin: A one-way cryptographic function that maps input data to a fixed-size digest, used in integrity verification, authentication, and data indexing.
hashing.use_case: A login system stores hashed passwords to avoid keeping the originals in the database.

salting.eli5: It’s like adding secret seasoning to your password before storing it so hackers can't guess the recipe.
salting.boss: Salting strengthens password storage by adding random data before hashing to prevent dictionary and rainbow table attacks.
salting.sysadmin: Salts are random values combined with passwords before hashing, ensuring unique hash outputs even for identical inputs.
salting.use_case: A website adds a salt to each user's password before hashing, making it harder to crack stolen hashes.

hmac.eli5: It’s like sealing a letter with a wax stamp so you know it’s from the right person and untouched.
hmac.boss: HMAC (Hash-based Message Authentication Code) ensures data integrity and authenticity by combining a hash function with a secret key.
hmac.sysadmin: HMAC uses cryptographic hash functions (like SHA-256) combined with a secret key to verify message authenticity and integrity in transit.
hmac.use_case: APIs often use HMAC to validate requests and prevent tampering in transit.

penetration testing.eli5: It’s like hiring a burglar to try and break into your house so you know what to fix.
penetration testing.boss: Penetration testing simulates cyberattacks to find and fix vulnerabilities before real attackers do.
penetration testing.sysadmin: Pen testing involves authorized attempts to exploit systems, applications, or networks to identify weaknesses and validate security posture.
penetration testing.use_case: A company hires a consultant to run a penetration test on its customer portal before launch.

red team.eli5: It’s like a group of ninjas hired to sneak into your castle to test your defenses.
red team.boss: A red team emulates real-world attackers to test an organization's defenses by simulating advanced threats.
red team.sysadmin: Red teams use adversarial tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) to assess detection, prevention, and incident response readiness.
red team.use_case: The red team simulates an insider threat attack to test an organization’s detection and response capabilities.

blue team.eli5: It’s the crew guarding your castle — watching cameras, checking locks, and sounding alarms.
blue team.boss: Blue teams are responsible for defending systems against attacks, monitoring activity, and responding to threats.
blue team.sysadmin: A blue team conducts continuous monitoring, threat detection, vulnerability management, and incident response to protect IT assets.
blue team.use_case: The blue team detects and blocks a simulated ransomware attack launched by the red team.

purple team.eli5: It’s like the red and blue teams working together — one tries to break in, the other learns how to stop them.
purple team.boss: Purple teams facilitate collaboration between red (attack) and blue (defense) teams to improve security through shared insights.
purple team.sysadmin: Purple teaming blends offensive testing and defensive tuning, enabling real-time knowledge transfer to strengthen detection and response.
purple team.use_case: A purple team runs a test where attackers simulate phishing and defenders enhance detection in real time.

white hat hacker.eli5: It’s a good guy hacker who helps fix things instead of breaking them.
white hat hacker.boss: White hat hackers use their skills ethically to help organizations find and fix security issues.
white hat hacker.sysadmin: Also known as ethical hackers, white hats are authorized individuals who conduct tests, report vulnerabilities, and assist in securing systems.
white hat hacker.use_case: A white hat discovers a vulnerability in an app and responsibly reports it to the vendor.

black hat hacker.eli5: It’s a bad guy hacker who breaks into systems to steal or cause harm.
black hat hacker.boss: Black hat hackers exploit systems illegally for personal gain, data theft, or disruption.
black hat hacker.sysadmin: These are unauthorized attackers who breach systems using malware, phishing, or exploits to steal data or damage infrastructure.
black hat hacker.use_case: A black hat hacker deploys ransomware to lock hospital systems and demand a payment.

gray hat hacker.eli5: It’s someone who breaks into places without permission but doesn’t mean harm — like an uninvited handyman.
gray hat hacker.boss: Gray hat hackers find and report vulnerabilities without malicious intent but often without authorization.
gray hat hacker.sysadmin: They operate in a legal gray area — not malicious, but not fully ethical either — discovering flaws without prior consent and sometimes disclosing them publicly.
gray hat hacker.use_case: A gray hat finds a bug in a government site and discloses it online after no response from officials.

bug bounty.eli5: It’s like a cash reward for finding holes in someone’s digital fence.
bug bounty.boss: Bug bounty programs pay ethical hackers for reporting vulnerabilities, helping companies find flaws before bad actors do.
bug bounty.sysadmin: Organizations offer bounties through platforms or directly to security researchers who responsibly disclose software or system vulnerabilities.
bug bounty.use_case: A researcher earns $5,000 from a bug bounty for finding an authentication flaw in a banking app.

vulnerability assessment.eli5: It’s like checking your house for unlocked doors and windows before a storm hits.
vulnerability assessment.boss: A vulnerability assessment scans systems to identify known security weaknesses before attackers find them.
vulnerability assessment.sysadmin: This process uses automated tools to scan systems, software, and configurations for vulnerabilities like outdated software, misconfigurations, and missing patches.
vulnerability assessment.use_case: An IT team runs weekly vulnerability assessments to identify outdated software across all servers.

security audit.eli5: It’s like a checklist review to make sure your locks, alarms, and lights are working as they should.
security audit.boss: A security audit evaluates an organization's policies, practices, and systems to ensure they meet security standards and compliance.
security audit.sysadmin: An internal or third-party review of systems, logs, and procedures to verify the effectiveness and enforcement of security controls and policies.
security audit.use_case: A company undergoes a security audit to verify compliance with ISO 27001 standards.

threat modeling.eli5: It’s like imagining all the ways burglars could break into your house so you can plan how to stop them.
threat modeling.boss: Threat modeling identifies and evaluates potential threats and weaknesses in a system’s design or architecture.
threat modeling.sysadmin: A proactive approach that maps out assets, threat actors, attack vectors, and mitigations to prioritize security controls during development.
threat modeling.use_case: Developers perform threat modeling during the design phase to build a more secure banking app.

risk assessment.eli5: It’s like figuring out which problems are most likely to happen and how bad they’d be.
risk assessment.boss: Risk assessments identify threats, vulnerabilities, and potential impacts to help prioritize security efforts.
risk assessment.sysadmin: A structured evaluation of assets, threats, vulnerabilities, and their likelihood and impact to determine security risk levels and mitigation needs.
risk assessment.use_case: An organization performs a risk assessment to decide whether to invest in DDoS protection.

security baseline.eli5: It’s like setting up your house with at least a lock and a peephole — the minimum expected security.
security baseline.boss: A security baseline defines the minimum security controls required for systems or applications to meet policy or compliance.
security baseline.sysadmin: It’s a standard configuration that enforces consistent security practices across devices and services, used as a reference for audits and deployments.
security baseline.use_case: A company deploys laptops with a Windows 11 security baseline that includes BitLocker and Defender enabled by default.

security hardening.eli5: It’s like putting bars on windows, not just locks on doors — extra layers of defense.
security hardening.boss: Security hardening removes unnecessary features and enforces strict configurations to reduce attack surfaces.
security hardening.sysadmin: The process of reducing vulnerabilities by disabling unused services, enforcing strong settings, applying patches, and applying security baselines.
security hardening.use_case: An admin disables legacy protocols and removes unused software from all new servers to harden them.

secure boot.eli5: It’s like checking your car’s ID before starting it to make sure it hasn’t been tampered with.
secure boot.boss: Secure Boot ensures that only trusted, signed software can load when a device powers on, preventing boot-time malware.
secure boot.sysadmin: A UEFI feature that checks digital signatures on bootloaders and OS kernels, blocking unauthorized or tampered code during startup.
secure boot.use_case: Secure Boot blocks a rootkit trying to load before the OS on a company laptop.

trusted platform module.eli5: It’s like a vault built into your computer that stores secrets and only opens for the right software.
trusted platform module.boss: The Trusted Platform Module (TPM) is a hardware chip that securely stores cryptographic keys and helps ensure system integrity.
trusted platform module.sysadmin: TPM is a hardware-based security chip that provides cryptographic functions such as secure key generation, device authentication, and attestation of system state.
trusted platform module.use_case: TPM is used to securely store the encryption keys for BitLocker on Windows machines.

uefi secure boot.eli5: It’s like having a bouncer at startup who only lets approved programs run when your computer turns on.
uefi secure boot.boss: UEFI Secure Boot checks digital signatures to ensure only trusted software runs during system startup.
uefi secure boot.sysadmin: A feature in UEFI firmware that validates the digital signatures of bootloaders and OS components to block tampered or unauthorized code.
aliases: Unified Extensible Firmware Interface Secure Boot
uefi secure boot.use_case: A company enables UEFI Secure Boot on all workstations to prevent rootkits from loading at startup.

zero trust.eli5: It’s like not trusting anyone in your house until they show ID at every door.
zero trust.boss: Zero Trust is a security model where nothing is trusted by default — users and devices must continuously prove they are authorized.
zero trust.sysadmin: Zero Trust Architecture enforces strict identity verification and continuous authentication regardless of network location, using principles like least privilege and segmentation.
zero trust.use_case: A business implements Zero Trust to require device and identity validation before accessing internal resources.

security posture.eli5: It’s like your home’s security score — how well you're protected against break-ins.
security posture.boss: Security posture is the overall strength and maturity of an organization’s security controls and policies.
security posture.sysadmin: Refers to the state of a system’s defenses, measured by its ability to identify, prevent, detect, and respond to threats based on policies, tools, and configurations.
security posture.use_case: A company reviews its security posture quarterly to ensure it's aligned with new threats and compliance needs.

defense in depth.eli5: It’s like having a moat, a wall, a locked door, and an alarm — layers of protection.
defense in depth.boss: Defense in depth is a strategy that uses multiple overlapping security layers to reduce the chance of successful attacks.
defense in depth.sysadmin: A security design principle that layers technical, physical, and administrative controls to delay or stop intrusions even if one layer fails.
defense in depth.use_case: A business uses firewalls, MFA, endpoint protection, and encryption as part of a defense in depth strategy.

least privilege.eli5: It’s like giving your dog walker a key that only opens the front door — nothing else.
least privilege.boss: Least privilege means giving users and systems only the minimum access they need to do their jobs — nothing more.
least privilege.sysadmin: A principle where users, applications, and systems are granted the lowest level of access necessary, reducing risk of misuse or compromise.
least privilege.use_case: Developers only have access to staging servers, while production access is limited to release engineers.

security by design.eli5: It’s like building a house with locks on every door from the start instead of adding them later.
security by design.boss: Security by design means embedding protection into systems and software from the start, rather than patching later.
security by design.sysadmin: An approach where security is prioritized during the initial architecture and design of systems, ensuring risks are addressed proactively.
security by design.use_case: A software team includes threat modeling and secure architecture reviews before writing any production code.

security awareness training.eli5: It’s like teaching everyone at home how to spot a scammer at the door.
security awareness training.boss: Security awareness training educates employees on recognizing and avoiding cyber threats like phishing, social engineering, and unsafe behavior.
security awareness training.sysadmin: Training programs designed to teach users security best practices, policy compliance, and how to recognize and report suspicious activity.
security awareness training.use_case: Staff complete monthly phishing simulations and training to improve the company’s human security layer.

patch management.eli5: It’s like fixing cracks in your walls so bugs can’t get in.
patch management.boss: Patch management is the process of updating software to fix bugs and security flaws before attackers exploit them.
patch management.sysadmin: This involves identifying, testing, deploying, and verifying updates for OSes, applications, and firmware to remediate vulnerabilities.
patch management.use_case: The IT team uses automated tools to deploy security patches across all Windows and Linux systems every week.

software updates.eli5: It’s like getting a tune-up for your car so it runs better and safer.
software updates.boss: Software updates include new features, bug fixes, and critical security patches that keep systems safe and functional.
software updates.sysadmin: The routine deployment of updated software versions to fix security issues, improve performance, or enhance functionality.
software updates.use_case: A user installs the latest OS update that includes a fix for a known remote code execution flaw.

configuration management.eli5: It’s like keeping track of all the settings and knobs on your machines so nothing breaks.
configuration management.boss: Configuration management ensures systems are set up consistently and stay secure by controlling settings and changes.
configuration management.sysadmin: A process and set of tools for standardizing system setups, tracking configuration changes, and enforcing desired states across infrastructure.
configuration management.use_case: Ansible is used to enforce server configurations and automatically revert unauthorized changes.

secure coding.eli5: It’s like writing instructions with built-in safety checks so nothing bad can happen.
secure coding.boss: Secure coding is the practice of writing software that prevents vulnerabilities like injection, leaks, or exploits.
secure coding.sysadmin: A software development discipline that follows coding standards and threat modeling to avoid introducing common vulnerabilities during development.
secure coding.use_case: Developers sanitize all user inputs to prevent cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.

devsecops.eli5: It’s like building and testing with a security guard sitting in the room.
devsecops.boss: DevSecOps integrates security practices into every phase of software development and delivery.
devsecops.sysadmin: A development methodology where security is a shared responsibility from planning to deployment, using automation and collaboration across dev, security, and ops.
devsecops.use_case: A DevSecOps pipeline automatically runs SAST, DAST, and dependency scans on every pull request.

security testing.eli5: It’s like shaking the doors and windows of a house to see if anything opens that shouldn’t.
security testing.boss: Security testing checks software or systems for vulnerabilities, misconfigurations, or weak defenses.
security testing.sysadmin: An umbrella term for testing methods like SAST, DAST, fuzzing, and scanning to identify and resolve security weaknesses.
security testing.use_case: Before launching an app, the QA team runs security tests to check for injection flaws and insecure authentication.

code review.eli5: It’s like having a second pair of eyes look over your work to catch mistakes.
code review.boss: Code reviews ensure quality and security by letting team members inspect changes before they’re merged.
code review.sysadmin: A collaborative process where peers examine code changes for bugs, insecure patterns, and compliance with best practices before deployment.
code review.use_case: Each pull request must be approved by at least one teammate through a code review.

static application security testing.eli5: It’s like reading code line-by-line to find hidden security traps before running it.
static application security testing.boss: SAST tools analyze source code to detect security flaws early in the development process.
static application security testing.sysadmin: SAST performs static analysis of source code or binaries without executing them, finding issues like hardcoded credentials or injection risks.
static application security testing.use_case: A SAST scanner flags insecure password storage in source code during CI/CD builds.

dynamic application security testing.eli5: It’s like poking a running app from the outside to see if it reacts badly.
dynamic application security testing.boss: DAST tests live applications to find vulnerabilities like injection, broken authentication, or logic flaws.
dynamic application security testing.sysadmin: DAST simulates attacks against running applications, analyzing runtime behavior and inputs to identify exploitable weaknesses.
dynamic application security testing.use_case: A DAST tool scans a deployed web app and reports a reflected XSS vulnerability.

runtime application self-protection.eli5: It’s like your app having its own bodyguard that steps in if something fishy happens.
runtime application self-protection.boss: RASP monitors applications in real time to detect and stop malicious behavior as it occurs.
runtime application self-protection.sysadmin: RASP integrates into application runtime, analyzing behavior and inputs to block attacks like SQL injection or command execution on the fly.
runtime application self-protection.use_case: RASP blocks a malicious input that tries to exploit an injection vulnerability in a production API.

log4shell.eli5: It’s like shouting a phrase at someone’s smart speaker and suddenly gaining access to their whole house.
log4shell.boss: Log4Shell was a severe vulnerability in the Log4j logging library that allowed remote code execution via crafted log messages.
log4shell.sysadmin: A critical CVE (CVE-2021-44228) in Apache Log4j enabling attackers to exploit JNDI lookups and execute arbitrary code remotely.
log4shell.use_case: Attackers exploited Log4Shell in vulnerable systems to deploy crypto miners and backdoors before it was patched.

heartbleed.eli5: It’s like a nosy neighbor asking ‘how are you?’ and getting your private letters in response.
heartbleed.boss: Heartbleed was a bug in OpenSSL that let attackers read sensitive memory from affected systems.
heartbleed.sysadmin: A vulnerability in OpenSSL’s heartbeat implementation (CVE-2014-0160) that allowed unauthorized reading of memory up to 64KB, exposing credentials and data.
heartbleed.use_case: Heartbleed exposed passwords and private keys from millions of web servers using OpenSSL.

shellshock.eli5: It’s like whispering magic words to someone’s walkie-talkie and getting them to do anything you want.
shellshock.boss: Shellshock was a serious flaw in the Bash shell that allowed remote command execution via environment variables.
shellshock.sysadmin: A vulnerability in GNU Bash (CVE-2014-6271) that let attackers run arbitrary code through specially crafted environment variables, affecting many Unix systems.
shellshock.use_case: Shellshock was used in automated attacks on web servers using CGI scripts with Bash.

spectre.eli5: It’s like convincing your brain to peek at secrets it wasn’t supposed to see — by asking nicely and fast.
spectre.boss: Spectre is a hardware flaw in CPUs that lets attackers trick programs into leaking sensitive data.
spectre.sysadmin: A class of speculative execution side-channel attacks affecting modern CPUs, allowing reading of memory from other processes (CVE-2017-5753, -5715).
spectre.use_case: Spectre prompted OS and browser updates to prevent attackers from reading passwords in memory.

meltdown.eli5: It’s like being able to sneak a peek into the safe while someone else has it open.
meltdown.boss: Meltdown is a CPU vulnerability that lets attackers read protected memory, bypassing system boundaries.
meltdown.sysadmin: A hardware flaw (CVE-2017-5754) in Intel CPUs allowing user processes to read kernel memory via out-of-order execution and side-channel attacks.
meltdown.use_case: Meltdown forced OS vendors to redesign memory isolation between kernel and user space.

bluekeep.eli5: It’s like a hidden trapdoor in millions of homes that anyone on the internet could walk through.
bluekeep.boss: BlueKeep is a critical vulnerability in Windows Remote Desktop that allowed unauthenticated remote code execution.
bluekeep.sysadmin: A wormable RDP flaw (CVE-2019-0708) in older Windows systems enabling remote code execution without authentication via specially crafted RDP packets.
bluekeep.use_case: Unpatched Windows 7 machines were exploited using BlueKeep to install cryptocurrency miners.

eternalblue.eli5: It’s like a lockpick tool that works on millions of doors — and it got leaked online.
eternalblue.boss: EternalBlue is an NSA-developed exploit for Windows SMB vulnerabilities later used in major ransomware attacks.
eternalblue.sysadmin: A leaked SMBv1 exploit (CVE-2017-0144) targeting Microsoft Windows, used by WannaCry and NotPetya for self-propagating malware.
eternalblue.use_case: EternalBlue was used to spread WannaCry ransomware across unpatched networks in 2017.

owasp.eli5: It’s like a club of good hackers who share tips on how to keep websites safe.
owasp.boss: OWASP is a nonprofit focused on improving software security through open-source tools, research, and community-driven best practices.
owasp.sysadmin: The Open Worldwide Application Security Project (OWASP) provides free resources and tools for identifying, preventing, and mitigating software vulnerabilities.
owasp.use_case: A development team uses OWASP documentation to guide secure coding practices in their web app.

owasp top 10.eli5: It’s like the ‘most wanted’ list for website problems that hackers love to target.
owasp top 10.boss: The OWASP Top 10 is a list of the most critical web application security risks, updated regularly to reflect real-world threats.
owasp top 10.sysadmin: A widely used awareness document from OWASP outlining the ten most common and dangerous vulnerabilities found in web applications.
owasp top 10.use_case: A company prioritizes remediating injection and authentication flaws using the OWASP Top 10 as a checklist.

cwe.eli5: It’s like a big dictionary of all the common ways software can mess up.
cwe.boss: CWE (Common Weakness Enumeration) is a categorized list of software flaws used to identify and prevent vulnerabilities.
cwe.sysadmin: A MITRE-maintained classification system that organizes and standardizes software weakness types for tools, analysts, and developers.
cwe.use_case: Developers use CWE IDs to track and fix recurring coding issues in bug tracking systems.

cve.eli5: It’s like a license plate number for each known software bug that could hurt you.
cve.boss: CVEs (Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures) are standardized IDs for publicly disclosed cybersecurity flaws.
cve.sysadmin: CVE is a database maintained by MITRE assigning unique identifiers to publicly known vulnerabilities across software and hardware products.
cve.use_case: A vulnerability scanner flags systems affected by CVE-2021-44228 (Log4Shell).

cvss.eli5: It’s like a danger meter for computer bugs — the higher the score, the scarier it is.
cvss.boss: CVSS (Common Vulnerability Scoring System) is a standardized way to rate the severity of security flaws from 0 to 10.
cvss.sysadmin: CVSS calculates scores based on factors like attack complexity, exploitability, and impact, helping prioritize vulnerability remediation.
cvss.use_case: A security team patches all vulnerabilities with a CVSS score of 7.0 or higher as part of their SLA.

nist.eli5: It’s like a group of scientists who make important rules and measurements — including how to stay safe online.
nist.boss: NIST is a U.S. agency that develops cybersecurity standards, frameworks, and guidelines used worldwide.
nist.sysadmin: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) publishes frameworks like NIST 800-53 for system hardening, compliance, and risk management.
aliases: National Institute of Standards and Technology
nist.use_case: A federal contractor uses NIST 800-171 to guide how sensitive data should be protected.

nist cybersecurity framework.eli5: It’s like a five-step plan to help businesses stay safe from cyber bad guys.
nist cybersecurity framework.boss: The NIST Cybersecurity Framework provides structured guidance for identifying, protecting, detecting, responding to, and recovering from cyber threats.
nist cybersecurity framework.sysadmin: A voluntary framework that outlines best practices and control families across five core functions: Identify, Protect, Detect, Respond, and Recover.
nist cybersecurity framework.use_case: A small business adopts the NIST Cybersecurity Framework to improve their risk posture without needing full compliance frameworks.

mitre att&ck.eli5: It’s like a big playbook showing all the tricks hackers use, from start to finish.
mitre att&ck.boss: MITRE ATT&CK is a knowledge base that maps out real-world attacker tactics and techniques for cybersecurity defense.
mitre att&ck.sysadmin: MITRE ATT&CK (Adversarial Tactics, Techniques & Common Knowledge) is a globally used framework for understanding attacker behavior across different stages of an intrusion.
aliases: Adversarial Tactics Techniques and Common Knowledge
mitre att&ck.use_case: A security team uses MITRE ATT&CK to align detection rules with common adversary behavior.

cyber kill chain.eli5: It’s like breaking down a burglary into steps — from planning to getting caught — so you can stop it early.
cyber kill chain.boss: The Cyber Kill Chain models the stages of a cyberattack, helping organizations detect and disrupt attacks before they succeed.
cyber kill chain.sysadmin: A framework developed by Lockheed Martin describing 7 phases of an attack: reconnaissance, weaponization, delivery, exploitation, installation, command & control, and actions on objectives.
cyber kill chain.use_case: Security teams use the Cyber Kill Chain to identify what phase an attacker is in and respond appropriately.

iso 27001.eli5: It’s like getting a gold star that says your company follows really good security rules.
iso 27001.boss: ISO 27001 is an international standard for managing information security, often required for compliance and business credibility.
iso 27001.sysadmin: A certifiable framework that sets requirements for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continually improving an information security management system (ISMS).
iso 27001.use_case: A SaaS company achieves ISO 27001 certification to meet client security expectations and expand into regulated markets.

soc 2.eli5: It’s like a report card that shows a company handles your data safely and responsibly.
soc 2.boss: SOC 2 is a widely recognized audit that evaluates how well a service provider protects customer data across security, availability, and confidentiality.
soc 2.sysadmin: SOC 2 (System and Organization Controls) is a framework for reporting on controls relevant to security, availability, processing integrity, confidentiality, and privacy.
soc 2.use_case: A cloud provider undergoes a SOC 2 audit annually to assure clients their infrastructure meets security standards.

pci dss.eli5: It’s like the rules all stores must follow when taking your credit card — to keep it safe.
pci dss.boss: PCI DSS is a compliance standard required for companies that handle credit card data, ensuring secure processing and storage.
pci dss.sysadmin: The Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard (PCI DSS) mandates technical and operational controls to protect cardholder data across systems and processes.
aliases: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard
pci dss.use_case: An online store uses tokenization and strong access controls to meet PCI DSS requirements.

hipaa.eli5: It’s like the law that keeps your medical records private and safe.
hipaa.boss: HIPAA is a U.S. regulation that protects sensitive health data and mandates how it can be stored, shared, and secured.
hipaa.sysadmin: The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act sets standards for safeguarding protected health information (PHI) through administrative, physical, and technical safeguards.
aliases: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act
hipaa.use_case: A healthcare provider encrypts patient records and controls access to comply with HIPAA.

gdpr.eli5: It’s the rule that says companies have to ask before collecting your personal info — or face big fines.
gdpr.boss: The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is a privacy law that governs how personal data is collected, stored, and shared in the EU.
gdpr.sysadmin: A European Union regulation that enforces strict rules on data collection, processing, consent, and breach notification, applying to organizations handling EU citizens’ data.
gdpr.use_case: A website adds cookie consent banners and data export options to comply with GDPR.

security operations center.eli5: It’s like a digital security HQ where experts watch for hackers and sound the alarm.
security operations center.boss: A Security Operations Center (SOC) monitors and defends an organization’s digital infrastructure from threats 24/7.
security operations center.sysadmin: The SOC is a centralized team and facility equipped with tools like SIEMs to monitor, detect, investigate, and respond to security incidents in real time.
security operations center.use_case: A SOC identifies an unusual login pattern and blocks access before a breach occurs.

incident response plan.eli5: It’s like a fire drill plan, but for when hackers break in.
incident response plan.boss: An Incident Response Plan (IRP) outlines steps an organization takes when a cybersecurity incident occurs to minimize damage and recover quickly.
incident response plan.sysadmin: A structured document detailing roles, procedures, and communication flows for detecting, containing, eradicating, and recovering from cybersecurity incidents.
incident response plan.use_case: An organization follows its IRP after detecting ransomware, isolating systems and notifying affected customers.

playbook.eli5: It’s like a step-by-step recipe that tells you what to do when something goes wrong.
playbook.boss: A cybersecurity playbook is a predefined set of actions for responding to specific types of threats or incidents.
playbook.sysadmin: Playbooks standardize response actions for different scenarios, like phishing or malware outbreaks, enabling quick and repeatable incident handling.
playbook.use_case: A phishing playbook guides analysts through email header analysis, user notification, and blocking malicious domains.

incident detection.eli5: It’s like your burglar alarm going off when someone tries to sneak in.
incident detection.boss: Incident detection is the process of identifying signs that a cybersecurity event or breach may be occurring.
incident detection.sysadmin: Detection involves monitoring systems and analyzing alerts from SIEMs, IDS/IPS, and endpoints for suspicious behavior or known attack patterns.
incident detection.use_case: A spike in failed login attempts triggers incident detection mechanisms, alerting the SOC team.

triage.eli5: It’s like deciding which fire to put out first when everything's going wrong.
triage.boss: Triage helps security teams prioritize incidents based on severity, impact, and urgency.
triage.sysadmin: Triage is the initial assessment of alerts or incidents to determine their credibility, scope, and necessary response level.
triage.use_case: A SOC analyst triages multiple alerts, escalating only those that involve privileged account activity.

forensics.eli5: It’s like a digital detective figuring out what happened after a break-in.
forensics.boss: Forensics involves collecting and analyzing digital evidence after a cyber incident to understand what happened and how.
forensics.sysadmin: Digital forensics includes memory dumps, log reviews, and file system analysis to reconstruct attacker actions and preserve evidence.
forensics.use_case: A forensic team analyzes system logs and disk images to trace the source of a data breach.

root cause analysis.eli5: It’s like figuring out which leaky pipe caused the flood in your basement.
root cause analysis.boss: Root cause analysis investigates the origin of a security incident to prevent it from happening again.
root cause analysis.sysadmin: A methodical investigation to trace a breach or failure to its underlying technical, human, or procedural origin.
root cause analysis.use_case: After a data breach, RCA reveals it was caused by an unpatched third-party plugin.

containment.eli5: It’s like shutting a door to stop a fire from spreading through your house.
containment.boss: Containment is the step in incident response where the threat is isolated to prevent further damage.
containment.sysadmin: A phase where infected systems are quarantined, accounts disabled, or network segments isolated to stop attacker movement.
containment.use_case: Security tools automatically isolate a compromised server from the network to contain ransomware.

eradication.eli5: It’s like removing the infection after you’ve stopped it from spreading.
eradication.boss: Eradication removes the root cause and remnants of a security incident to ensure it can't come back.
eradication.sysadmin: This phase involves cleaning systems of malware, removing malicious accounts, and patching exploited vulnerabilities after containment.
eradication.use_case: The team removes a web shell from a compromised server and updates all vulnerable plugins.

recovery.eli5: It’s like repairing your home after stopping a fire — getting everything back to normal.
recovery.boss: Recovery is about restoring operations and verifying systems are clean and safe after an incident.
recovery.sysadmin: In this phase, services are brought back online, systems restored from clean backups, and validations performed to ensure threats are fully removed.
recovery.use_case: The IT team restores business services after rebuilding and patching affected systems.

post-incident review.eli5: It’s like a team huddle after an emergency to figure out what went well and what didn’t.
post-incident review.boss: A post-incident review analyzes how an incident was handled and identifies improvements to prevent recurrence.
post-incident review.sysadmin: A retrospective analysis where teams review timeline, detection, containment, and communication efforts to strengthen future incident response.
post-incident review.use_case: After a phishing incident, the team holds a post-incident review to improve email filters and awareness training.

siem tools.eli5: They’re like super-smart logs that help you spot trouble in your computer systems.
siem tools.boss: SIEM tools collect, analyze, and correlate security logs from across your network to detect threats and support compliance.
siem tools.sysadmin: Security Information and Event Management (SIEM) tools aggregate logs from various sources, apply correlation rules, and generate alerts for incident detection and response.
siem tools.use_case: A SOC uses a SIEM tool to monitor login events and alert on suspicious activity across cloud and on-prem systems.

splunk.eli5: It’s like a giant detective that reads all your computer logs and points out weird stuff.
splunk.boss: Splunk is a powerful platform for collecting and analyzing logs and machine data, often used in security and operations.
splunk.sysadmin: Splunk ingests logs, metrics, and events, enabling real-time visualization, search, and alerting for security monitoring and infrastructure troubleshooting.
splunk.use_case: The SOC uses Splunk dashboards to track failed logins and detect brute force attempts.

qradar.eli5: It’s IBM’s brain for spotting and alerting on cyberattacks based on your logs.
qradar.boss: QRadar is IBM’s SIEM platform that detects and investigates security incidents using data correlation and threat intelligence.
qradar.sysadmin: IBM QRadar collects and analyzes security logs and network traffic to detect anomalies, provide threat insights, and automate incident response.
qradar.use_case: A large enterprise uses QRadar to monitor firewall and endpoint logs for signs of compromise.

elastic security.eli5: It’s like an all-in-one security toolkit built on top of a search engine.
elastic security.boss: Elastic Security is part of the Elastic Stack, offering SIEM, threat hunting, and endpoint protection in one platform.
elastic security.sysadmin: Built on Elasticsearch and Kibana, Elastic Security combines log analytics, threat detection rules, and machine learning for unified security operations.
elastic security.use_case: A DevOps team uses Elastic Security to detect threats and correlate events across cloud infrastructure.

logrhythm.eli5: It’s a tool that listens to all the beeps and buzzes in your system and alerts you when something sounds wrong.
logrhythm.boss: LogRhythm is a SIEM platform that helps detect, investigate, and respond to security incidents using analytics and automation.
logrhythm.sysadmin: A centralized log and event correlation platform that supports threat detection, compliance, and response workflows across hybrid environments.
logrhythm.use_case: An MSSP uses LogRhythm to provide 24/7 log monitoring and alert triage for its clients.

microsoft sentinel.eli5: It’s Microsoft’s watchtower for spotting danger in your digital world — and sounding the alarm.
microsoft sentinel.boss: Microsoft Sentinel is a cloud-native SIEM and SOAR platform that monitors, detects, and responds to security threats across environments.
microsoft sentinel.sysadmin: Sentinel integrates with Azure and third-party systems to ingest logs, apply analytics, detect anomalies, and trigger automated responses.
microsoft sentinel.use_case: An IT team uses Sentinel to detect threats across Microsoft 365, Azure, and on-prem infrastructure.

alienvault ossim.eli5: It’s a free superhero that scans your network and logs for danger signs.
alienvault ossim.boss: AlienVault OSSIM is an open-source SIEM solution combining log management, threat detection, and basic asset discovery.
alienvault ossim.sysadmin: OSSIM (Open Source Security Information Management) integrates with Snort, OSSEC, and other tools for log correlation and threat detection in smaller environments.
alienvault ossim.use_case: A small business uses AlienVault OSSIM to monitor internal traffic and detect brute-force attacks.

graylog.eli5: It’s a tool that reads your computer’s logs and helps you make sense of the chatter.
graylog.boss: Graylog is an open-source log management platform used for analyzing and visualizing machine data in real time.
graylog.sysadmin: Graylog collects and parses structured logs from various sources, offering a centralized dashboard for search, correlation, and alerting.
graylog.use_case: A security team uses Graylog to monitor failed logins and track firewall activity from remote offices.

cybersecurity roles.eli5: It’s like having guards, detectives, and doctors all working together to protect your digital home.
cybersecurity roles.boss: Cybersecurity roles include various specialists who design, monitor, and defend systems against cyber threats.
cybersecurity roles.sysadmin: Roles in cybersecurity span from analysts and engineers to leadership positions like CISOs, each contributing to incident prevention, detection, response, and strategy.
cybersecurity roles.use_case: A company builds out its cybersecurity team with engineers, analysts, and a GRC specialist to cover all areas of risk.

security analyst.eli5: They’re like the first responder who watches all the cameras and sounds the alarm when something looks fishy.
security analyst.boss: A security analyst monitors systems for threats, investigates alerts, and helps keep digital assets safe.
security analyst.sysadmin: This role involves real-time monitoring, triage of security events, incident documentation, and threat research across SIEMs and endpoints.
security analyst.use_case: A security analyst investigates suspicious outbound traffic that may indicate data exfiltration.

security engineer.eli5: They build and maintain the locks, cameras, and fences that protect your digital house.
security engineer.boss: A security engineer designs and implements tools and systems to prevent cyberattacks.
security engineer.sysadmin: Engineers develop and maintain security infrastructure like firewalls, endpoint protection, authentication systems, and logging pipelines.
security engineer.use_case: A security engineer configures and maintains the company’s VPN, firewall, and MFA setup.

security architect.eli5: They’re like the blueprint designer for a fortress — making sure all the parts fit together and stay secure.
security architect.boss: A security architect defines high-level security strategies and systems across infrastructure, apps, and users.
security architect.sysadmin: This senior role designs end-to-end security frameworks, chooses technical controls, and sets architecture standards aligned with business needs.
security architect.use_case: A security architect leads the shift to a Zero Trust architecture across a multi-cloud environment.

ciso.eli5: They’re the head of security — the one responsible for keeping everything and everyone safe from digital threats.
ciso.boss: The Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) oversees cybersecurity strategy, risk, and compliance across the organization.
ciso.sysadmin: A senior executive who sets policies, leads teams, allocates budgets, and ensures alignment between security objectives and business goals.
ciso.use_case: The CISO presents quarterly reports on data breaches and security metrics to the board.

soc analyst.eli5: They sit in a digital command center, watching for alarms and deciding what to do when one goes off.
soc analyst.boss: A SOC analyst monitors, detects, and responds to threats in a Security Operations Center (SOC).
soc analyst.sysadmin: They review alerts, correlate incidents, follow playbooks, and escalate threats — often working in shifts to provide 24/7 monitoring.
soc analyst.use_case: A SOC analyst detects unusual lateral movement and escalates it for containment.

penetration tester.eli5: They’re hired hackers who break in — legally — to show where the cracks are.
penetration tester.boss: Penetration testers simulate attacks to find weaknesses in systems before real hackers do.
penetration tester.sysadmin: Pen testers use tools and manual techniques to exploit vulnerabilities in apps, networks, and devices, providing remediation guidance afterward.
penetration tester.use_case: A penetration tester gains access to internal systems using a misconfigured web server and writes a report to fix it.

threat hunter.eli5: They’re like bounty hunters for cyber threats — actively searching for signs of bad guys inside the system.
threat hunter.boss: Threat hunters proactively search for undetected threats within an organization’s systems.
threat hunter.sysadmin: They use threat intelligence, analytics, and intuition to uncover stealthy or advanced threats missed by automated tools.
threat hunter.use_case: A threat hunter discovers persistence techniques from a stealthy attacker hiding in PowerShell logs.

incident responder.eli5: They’re the firefighters of cybersecurity — rushing in when alarms go off to contain the blaze.
incident responder.boss: Incident responders act fast to contain, analyze, and remediate cybersecurity incidents.
incident responder.sysadmin: These specialists follow incident response plans, isolate threats, gather forensics, and coordinate recovery efforts.
incident responder.use_case: An incident responder quarantines infected devices and coordinates with legal and PR during a ransomware event.

forensic analyst.eli5: They piece together what happened after a digital crime, like a high-tech detective.
forensic analyst.boss: A forensic analyst investigates digital evidence to understand how breaches happened and what was affected.
forensic analyst.sysadmin: They examine disk images, memory captures, logs, and file systems to reconstruct attacker actions and support legal or internal inquiries.
forensic analyst.use_case: A forensic analyst examines a compromised server to identify how data was exfiltrated.

grc analyst.eli5: They’re the rule-checkers who make sure everyone follows security laws and company policies.
grc analyst.boss: A GRC (Governance, Risk, and Compliance) analyst helps ensure cybersecurity aligns with legal and business requirements.
grc analyst.sysadmin: This role involves evaluating risk, creating policies, tracking compliance with frameworks like SOC 2 or ISO 27001, and reporting on security posture.
grc analyst.use_case: The GRC analyst helps complete a customer security questionnaire and maps internal policies to ISO controls.

secure email gateway.eli5: It’s like a mailroom guard that checks your letters for bombs before letting them in.
secure email gateway.boss: A Secure Email Gateway filters inbound and outbound email to stop phishing, malware, and spam.
secure email gateway.sysadmin: SEG systems scan email headers, attachments, and content using threat intelligence and heuristics to detect and block threats before they reach inboxes.
secure email gateway.use_case: The SEG blocks a spear-phishing attempt with a spoofed executive email address.

secure web gateway.eli5: It’s like a web bouncer that stops you from visiting dangerous or forbidden websites.
secure web gateway.boss: A Secure Web Gateway (SWG) protects users by filtering internet traffic to block malware, phishing, and policy violations.
secure web gateway.sysadmin: SWGs inspect outbound web traffic for malicious URLs, enforce acceptable use policies, and often include SSL decryption and DNS filtering.
secure web gateway.use_case: The SWG blocks users from accessing a known malware domain in real time.

cloud access security broker.eli5: It’s like a digital hall monitor that makes sure your cloud apps are being used safely.
cloud access security broker.boss: CASBs sit between users and cloud services, providing visibility, control, and security policy enforcement.
cloud access security broker.sysadmin: Cloud Access Security Brokers offer data loss prevention, user behavior monitoring, malware protection, and encryption for cloud apps like Office 365 or Google Workspace.
cloud access security broker.use_case: A CASB blocks file sharing on unauthorized cloud storage apps while allowing collaboration in sanctioned ones.

zero trust network access.eli5: It’s like checking someone’s ID every time they walk into a room, even if you saw them a minute ago.
zero trust network access.boss: Zero Trust Network Access (ZTNA) verifies every user and device before granting access to applications — regardless of location.
zero trust network access.sysadmin: ZTNA replaces traditional VPNs by enforcing authentication, device posture checks, and app-level access for every connection attempt.
zero trust network access.use_case: Remote users access internal apps through ZTNA after identity and device verification — no full network access needed.

network access control.eli5: It’s like a bouncer who only lets devices into the party if they’re on the guest list and dressed right.
network access control.boss: Network Access Control (NAC) checks whether a device meets security policies before it can connect to the network.
network access control.sysadmin: NAC solutions evaluate device health, compliance, and user credentials, enforcing access policies through switches or agents before allowing network communication.
network access control.use_case: NAC blocks unpatched personal laptops from connecting to the corporate LAN.

privileged access management.eli5: It’s like a special vault for master keys, with extra locks, alarms, and a sign-out sheet.
privileged access management.boss: Privileged Access Management (PAM) controls and monitors the use of high-level accounts to reduce the risk of misuse or compromise.
