contentful.sysadmin: Contentful offers a web UI for structured content and delivers it via REST and GraphQL APIs. It supports localization, webhooks, and media management.
contentful.use_case: Used to feed product details to both a mobile app and an online store from a single backend.

directus.eli5: It’s like giving your database a nice dashboard so non-tech folks can manage stuff too.
directus.boss: Directus is an open-source headless CMS that turns any SQL database into a content management platform with an admin UI.
directus.sysadmin: Directus connects to existing SQL databases and creates a metadata layer and API on top, supporting REST, GraphQL, roles, and versioning.
directus.use_case: Used to allow editors to manage data in a PostgreSQL database without touching code.

netlify cms.eli5: It’s like a content editor for static websites—add a blog post and it updates your site automatically.
netlify cms.boss: Netlify CMS is an open-source content editor for static sites, designed to work with Git-based workflows.
netlify cms.sysadmin: Netlify CMS stores content in Markdown or JSON files in a Git repo and triggers site builds on save. It supports custom widgets and identity management.
netlify cms.use_case: Used by non-devs to edit a Jekyll blog hosted on Netlify without touching code.

api.eli5: It’s a way for apps to talk to each other and ask for stuff like data or actions.
api.boss: An API (Application Programming Interface) lets different software systems communicate and exchange data.
api.sysadmin: APIs define a set of rules and endpoints for applications to send and receive data over protocols like HTTP, often using JSON or XML payloads.
api.use_case: Used to fetch weather data from a third-party service and display it in a web app.

api endpoint.eli5: It’s the exact web address where an app asks for something from another app.
api endpoint.boss: An API endpoint is a specific URL where an application accesses or sends data in an API.
api endpoint.sysadmin: Endpoints represent routes like `/users`, `/orders` in REST APIs and define interaction points for GET, POST, PUT, or DELETE operations.
api endpoint.use_case: Used to send new customer data to `/api/v1/customers` on a backend service.

rate limiting.eli5: It’s like a bouncer for APIs—it stops apps from asking too much too fast.
rate limiting.boss: Rate limiting controls how many requests a user or system can make to an API within a time frame to prevent abuse.
rate limiting.sysadmin: Rate limiting uses headers and server logic to track request volume (e.g., 100 requests per minute) and throttle or block excess traffic.
rate limiting.use_case: Used to limit free users to 60 API calls per minute in a SaaS platform.

bearer token.eli5: It’s like a secret pass—you show it when asking an API for something and it lets you in.
bearer token.boss: A bearer token is a type of access token used to authorize API requests without a username and password.
bearer token.sysadmin: Bearer tokens are included in HTTP headers (`Authorization: Bearer <token>`) to validate user identity in OAuth2 and JWT-based systems.
bearer token.use_case: Used to authenticate mobile app users making requests to a protected API.

oauth.eli5: It lets you log into apps using another account, like Google or Facebook.
oauth.boss: OAuth is a protocol that allows apps to access user information from another service without sharing passwords.
oauth.sysadmin: OAuth 1.0a uses signature-based authentication. It enables token exchange via request and access tokens between clients and authorization servers.
oauth.use_case: Used by a photo printing app to access your Instagram photos securely.

oauth2.eli5: It’s the newer, smoother way to let apps ask another app, ‘Hey, can I see this user’s stuff?’
oauth2.boss: OAuth2 is the modern standard for delegated authorization, used to grant apps access without passwords.
oauth2.sysadmin: OAuth2 supports flows like Authorization Code, Implicit, and Client Credentials. It issues short-lived access tokens for resource access and supports scopes.
oauth2.use_case: Used by third-party analytics tools to access Google Ads data securely.

openid connect.eli5: It lets apps say, ‘Who are you?’ and get a verified answer—like showing ID at the door.
openid connect.boss: OpenID Connect (OIDC) adds identity verification on top of OAuth2 to authenticate users securely.
openid connect.sysadmin: OIDC extends OAuth2 by providing an ID token (often JWT) and a user info endpoint for authentication. It supports SSO and federated logins.
openid connect.use_case: Used to log users into a web app with their Microsoft or Google account.

jwt.eli5: It’s a digital passport apps give you after logging in—so you don’t have to log in again right away.
jwt.boss: JWT (JSON Web Token) is a secure, compact way to transmit claims or identity between services.
jwt.sysadmin: JWTs contain base64-encoded headers, payloads, and signatures. They’re used in stateless authentication, often stored in cookies or localStorage.
jwt.use_case: Used to keep users logged in between page refreshes on a single-page app.

cookie.eli5: It’s a tiny note your browser saves to remember things like your login or preferences.
cookie.boss: Cookies store small bits of data in the browser, often used for sessions, tracking, or preferences.
cookie.sysadmin: Cookies are key-value pairs sent in HTTP headers. They support attributes like Secure, HttpOnly, and SameSite to enhance security and scope.
cookie.use_case: Used to keep users logged in between visits or remember dark mode settings.

session.eli5: It’s like your app's memory—what it knows about you while you're using it.
session.boss: A session stores data for a user during their visit to a website, like their login state or shopping cart.
session.sysadmin: Sessions can be stored in cookies, server memory, or external stores. They're identified by a session ID and expire after inactivity.
session.use_case: Used to track a user's progress through a checkout process on an e-commerce site.

csrf token.eli5: It’s a secret handshake that proves a request came from your app—not a sneaky copycat.
csrf token.boss: A CSRF token is used to verify that form submissions or API requests are legitimate and not forged by malicious sites.
csrf token.sysadmin: CSRF tokens are unique, unpredictable strings embedded in forms and verified on the server to prevent unauthorized actions from third-party origins.
csrf token.use_case: Used in login forms to prevent external sites from tricking users into submitting unauthorized actions.

api gateway.eli5: It’s a front door for all your APIs—it checks IDs, limits traffic, and sends requests to the right place.
api gateway.boss: An API Gateway manages and routes requests to microservices, enforcing security, monitoring, and rate limits.
api gateway.sysadmin: API Gateways handle routing, authentication, caching, throttling, and observability. Common examples include Kong, NGINX, and AWS API Gateway.
api gateway.use_case: Used to centralize access control and traffic routing for multiple internal APIs.

domain name.eli5: It’s the name you type to go to a website—like google.com instead of a bunch of numbers.
domain name.boss: A domain name is the human-friendly address used to access websites, mapped to IP addresses.
domain name.sysadmin: Domain names resolve through DNS to IP addresses. They're structured hierarchically (e.g., subdomain.domain.tld).
domain name.use_case: Used to make a personal portfolio accessible via johnsmith.dev.

tld.eli5: It’s the last part of a web address—like .com, .org, or .io.
tld.boss: A Top-Level Domain (TLD) is the suffix of a domain name that identifies its category or country.
tld.sysadmin: TLDs are managed by ICANN and include generic (gTLD) like `.com`, or country-specific (ccTLD) like `.uk`. They sit at the top of the DNS hierarchy.
tld.use_case: Used to choose a domain like myapp.io for a tech startup.

subdomain.eli5: It’s a prefix added to a website name—like a room inside a big house.
subdomain.boss: A subdomain is a subset of a domain, used to separate services or sections of a website.
subdomain.sysadmin: Subdomains (e.g., blog.example.com) are configured via DNS and treated as separate sites for routing or application isolation.
subdomain.use_case: Used to host a knowledge base at help.mysite.com separate from the main app.

name server.eli5: It’s a phone book that tells your browser how to find a website’s real address.
name server.boss: A name server maps domain names to IP addresses so browsers can locate the right servers.
name server.sysadmin: Name servers respond to DNS queries by returning IP addresses for domain names, supporting records like A, CNAME, and MX.
name server.use_case: Used to connect a domain from a registrar to a hosting provider’s servers.

cname.eli5: It’s like a nickname for a website—one address pointing to another.
cname.boss: A CNAME (Canonical Name) record is a DNS entry that points one domain name to another.
cname.sysadmin: CNAME records map one hostname to another, useful for pointing subdomains to services like GitHub Pages or SaaS platforms.
cname.use_case: Used to point blog.mysite.com to a blog hosted on a third-party service.

ttl.eli5: It’s a timer that tells computers how long to remember a website’s address before asking again.
ttl.boss: TTL (Time to Live) determines how long a DNS record is cached before it must be refreshed.
ttl.sysadmin: TTL values (in seconds) affect how frequently DNS resolvers query authoritative servers. Lower TTL allows faster changes; higher TTL improves caching.
ttl.use_case: Used to reduce TTL to 300 seconds before a domain migration for faster propagation.

hosting.eli5: It’s where your website lives so people can visit it online.
hosting.boss: Hosting is the service that stores your website files and makes them accessible on the internet.
hosting.sysadmin: Web hosting provides server space, bandwidth, and DNS configuration to serve static or dynamic content via HTTP/S protocols.
hosting.use_case: Used to launch a portfolio site on a shared hosting provider like Bluehost.

nginx.eli5: It’s a helper that hands out websites to visitors and makes sure they load fast.
nginx.boss: NGINX is a high-performance web server that handles static content, reverse proxying, and load balancing.
nginx.sysadmin: NGINX serves static files, proxies dynamic requests, manages SSL, and supports caching and load balancing for scalable web infrastructure.
nginx.use_case: Used to reverse proxy API requests to different backend microservices in a production stack.
